replication_study.hypothesis: Across countries, the interaction between cultural tightness and government efficiency is negatively associated with the COVID-19 infection growth rate, when the growth rate is operationalized as the country-level slope of the log of total cases per million over time (restricted to days after the country first exceeds 1 case per million and up to 2020-03-30), controlling for GDP per capita, median age, and Gini.

data_plan.source_type: Daily country-level COVID-19 surveillance (ECDC-derived) merged with World Bank/IMF/CIA indicators and Gelfand tightness index
data_plan.wave_or_subset: Country-days where total_covid_per_million > 1, restricted to 2019-12-31 through 2020-03-30 for growth-rate estimation
data_plan.sample_size: 63 countries present in the dataset; the analysis sample will be the subset with valid efficiency, tightness, and covariates and at least 3 days in the filtered window
data_plan.unit_of_analysis: Country (growth rates aggregated from country-day panel)
data_plan.access_details: Provided locally in replication_data; analysis script assumes all data files are mounted/available at /app/data

qualification.explanation: The dataset includes country-day COVID-19 cases/deaths and country-level cultural (tightness), institutional (government efficiency), and demographic/economic indicators necessary to reproduce the original study’s core infection growth rate analysis with the focal tightness × efficiency interaction.
qualification.similarity_to_original: The original study uses ECDC cases/deaths, World Bank Government Efficiency, Gelfand tightness, and economic/demographic controls (post_registration.json; original_paper.pdf summary). The provided dataset contains the same constructs: cases/deaths and cumulative totals (gelfand_replication_data.csv; gelfand_6708_data_dictionary.tsv), government efficiency (efficiency), cultural tightness (tightness), GDP per capita (gdp), Gini (gini_val/alternative_gini), and median age (median_age). The data dictionary explicitly notes filtering logic for ‘total_covid_per_million > 1’ and the early window (gelfand_6708_data_dictionary.tsv).
qualification.deviation_from_original: The replication restricts to dates up to 2020-03-30 based on data dictionary notes (obs_count_original) referencing the original period (gelfand_6708_data_dictionary.tsv). Some countries have missing efficiency (Kazakhstan, Sweden; data dictionary) and Gini values; we impute Gini from alternative_gini where available, mirroring notes in the data dictionary. The provided replication dataset includes 63 countries (get_dataset_variable_summary for country), which may be fewer than the 141 countries in the original (post_registration.json; original_paper.pdf summary), making this a partial sample replication.

data_plan.notes: Negative daily values may appear for cases/deaths for a few country-days per the data dictionary; the growth rate is computed from the log of total cases per million, which is positive by construction after filtering. Efficiency has NAs for some countries; Gini is constructed from gini_val else alternative_gini per data dictionary guidance. All IO is performed under /app/data. Weights are the number of included country-days per country during the filtered period.

steps: Filter to country-days with total_covid_per_million > 1 and date <= 2020-03-30.
For each country with at least 3 filtered days, regress log(total_covid_per_million) on a time index to estimate the country-level infection growth rate (slope).
Merge country-level predictors: cultural tightness, government efficiency, GDP per capita, median age, and Gini (using alternative_gini if gini_val is missing).
Standardize predictors (z-scores) and create the interaction term tightness_z × efficiency_z.

Run weighted OLS of growth_rate on tightness_z, efficiency_z, their interaction, and controls (gdp_z, median_age_z, gini_z), weighting by the number of country-days contributing to the growth-rate estimate; use robust (HC1) SEs.
Produce predicted growth rates at +/-1 SD combinations of tightness and efficiency with controls at means.
Save model summary and JSON outputs to /app/data.
planned_method.models: Weighted OLS with robust (HC1) standard errors; dependent variable is country-level growth rate (slope of log cases per million over time).
planned_method.outcome_variable: Country-level infection growth rate estimated as the slope from OLS of log(total cases per million) on time within each country.
planned_method.control_variables: gdp_z, median_age_z, gini_z (constructed from gini_val or alternative_gini).

planned_estimation_and_test.estimation: Coefficient for the interaction term (tight_x_eff_z) in the weighted OLS regression
planned_estimation_and_test.test: t-test on the interaction coefficient (two-sided), robust (HC1) SEs

planned_method.missing_data_handling: Listwise deletion for missing key predictors or growth rate; use alternative_gini when gini_val is missing as per data dictionary.
planned_method.multiple_testing_policy: Not applicable (single focal interaction test in the primary model).
planned_method.inference_criteria: Significance at alpha=0.05; expected direction is negative interaction.

files.gelfand_replication_analysis__py.py: Entry-point Python script. Reads /app/data/gelfand_replication_data.csv, filters to days with total_covid_per_million > 1 and date <= 2020-03-30, computes per-country infection growth rates, merges predictors, standardizes variables, estimates weighted OLS with robust SEs including tightness × efficiency and controls, outputs summary to /app/data/gelfand_replication_results.txt and structured results to /app/data/gelfand_replication_results.json.

codebase.notes: Ensure the CSV gelfand_replication_data.csv is available at /app/data when running. The script uses statsmodels WLS with HC1 SEs and follows the original early-period filtering logic described in the dataset documentation.

analysis.instructions: 1) Place gelfand_replication_data.csv at /app/data. 2) Run: python /app/code/gelfand_replication_analysis__py.py (or python data/original/19/0202_gpt5_nocode/replication_data/gelfand_replication_analysis__py.py inside the container with volumes mounted). 3) Inspect outputs at /app/data/gelfand_replication_results.txt and /app/data/gelfand_replication_results.json.
analysis.comparison_metrics: Compare sign and significance of the tightness × efficiency interaction, and the relative magnitudes/signs of tightness and efficiency main effects to the original (expected negative interaction; see initial_details.txt and post_registration.json). Optionally compare predicted growth rates at high vs low combinations.
